source.raw_text:
Thoracic rotations work muscles like the Trapezius, Rhomboids, Latissimus Dorsi, Erector Spinae, and Obliques, alongside stabilizers like the Rotatores, enhancing fundamental twisting and turning movement patterns crucial for daily life, sports, and preventing lower back strain by improving spinal health and core connection. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  
Muscles Worked 

• Superficial/Intermediate Back Muscles: Trapezius, Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Serratus Posterior Superior. 
• Deep Spinal Muscles: Erector Spinae (Spinalis), Transversospinalis Group (including Rotatores, Multifidus). 
• Core/Abdominal Muscles: External Obliques, Internal Obliques, Rectus Abdominis, Transversus Abdominis (assist with stabilization and rotation). 
• Chest Muscles: Pectorals (can be tight and restrict movement). [1, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10]  

Movement Patterns 

• Fundamental Motion: Rotation (twisting) of the thoracic spine (mid-back). 
• Combined Movements: Often combined with side bending (lateral flexion) and extension (arching) for fluid, circular motions. 
• Daily Activities: Enables reaching, twisting to get out of bed, gardening, and core-related tasks. 
• Sports: Essential for golf swings, throwing, surfing, and weight transfer in athletic movements. [2, 4, 6, 11]  

Why It's Important 

• Reduces Compensation: Prevents lower back and shoulder pain by reducing strain from restricted movement. 
• Improves Core Function: Enhances core connection, breathing, and stability. 
• Enhances Performance: Improves power transfer from lower to upper body. 
• Addresses Stiffness: Counteracts stiffness from prolonged sitting or poor posture. [2, 3, 6]
